stem: Applying anti‑spatter to jigs/fixtures can:

choices.text: Reduce spatter adhesion and cleanup time

rationales.CHOICE-2: Anti‑spatter on non‑weld surfaces reduces cleanup.

stem: Maintaining a short arc length generally:

rationales.CHOICE-1: Short arcs improve shielding effectiveness and bead control.

stem: To avoid hard spots and cracking from stray arc strikes, where should arc strikes be made?

choices.text: Anywhere on the base metal and ground later
Only within the joint area or on run‑on tabs
On machined surfaces away from the joint
On painted areas to protect the steel

rationales.CHOICE-2: Arc strikes can create hard spots/cracks; strike within the joint or on tabs, and remove any stray strikes per procedure.

stem: If a temporary backing strip is used and drawings require removal, you should:

choices.text: Leave it in place to save time
Remove and grind smooth per drawing/WPS after welding

rationales.CHOICE-2: Follow drawings/WPS for backing removal and finishing.

stem: Choosing an appropriate bevel angle helps to:

choices.text: Allow electrode/torch access and proper penetration

rationales.CHOICE-2: Adequate groove angle is required for access and fusion.

stem: To remove slag without damaging the base metal, a chipping hammer should be used at:

choices.text: A shallow angle with controlled blows
A steep angle with heavy blows

rationales.CHOICE-1: Use a shallow angle and controlled blows to avoid base‑metal damage.

stem: To maintain a consistent root gap during fit‑up, you should use:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use clamps and shims to set and hold uniform gaps.

stem: Why remove mill scale, paint, and oil before welding?

choices.text: They can cause porosity and lack of fusion

rationales.CHOICE-2: Contaminants produce gas and block fusion, causing defects.

stem: Maintaining consistent travel speed and arc length helps to:

choices.text: Produce uniform bead shape and fusion

rationales.CHOICE-2: Consistency supports uniform fusion and appearance.

stem: What should be done at the end of a weld bead?

choices.text: Blend and fill the crater before stopping
Strike a new arc on the finished face

rationales.CHOICE-2: Filling craters reduces the risk of crater cracking.

stem: At the end of a weld bead, a good practice is to:

choices.text: Fill and blend the crater before stopping
Strike off to the side and leave a crater

rationales.CHOICE-2: Filling the crater helps avoid cracking and underfill.

stem: Selecting a larger gas cup/nozzle in GTAW generally:

choices.text: Improves coverage for larger stickout if flow is adequate
Eliminates the need for a gas lens

rationales.CHOICE-1: Bigger cups can cover more area with proper flow and often with a gas lens.

stem: For out‑of‑position welding, using a smaller electrode diameter often:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Smaller electrodes help control the puddle overhead/vertical.

stem: Before welding over tack welds, you should:

choices.text: Feather/clean them to avoid lack of fusion

rationales.CHOICE-2: Feathered tacks blend smoothly into the weld.

stem: To avoid undercut on flat fillet welds, a common practice is to hold:

choices.text: An excessive travel angle and long arc
A ~45° work angle with a slight travel angle and short arc
A 90° work angle with no travel angle
The torch perpendicular to both plates

rationales.CHOICE-2: Proper work/travel angles and short arc reduce undercut.

stem: What does a fillet‑weld gauge measure?

choices.text: Fillet leg size or effective throat

rationales.CHOICE-2: Fillet gauges verify leg length and throat to drawing or code requirements.

stem: A fillet‑weld gauge is used to measure:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Gauges verify fillet size against requirements.

stem: Before welding galvanized steel, you should:

choices.text: Remove zinc coating locally and ensure ventilation

rationales.CHOICE-2: Removing zinc and ventilating reduces fume hazards and defects.

stem: Internal misalignment (hi‑lo) can be checked with:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use appropriate gauges to measure internal misalignment.

stem: Controlling interpass temperature primarily helps to:

choices.text: Control metallurgical properties and reduce cracking risk

rationales.CHOICE-2: Interpass control manages microstructure and cracking susceptibility.

stem: Peening of weld metal should be used:

choices.text: Heavily on root and final passes
Lightly on intermediate passes only if permitted by code/WPS
As a substitute for proper parameters

rationales.CHOICE-2: Peening can relieve stress but is restricted—avoid on root/final unless allowed.

stem: Changing welding polarity from what the WPS specifies may:

choices.text: Cause lack of fusion or instability

rationales.CHOICE-2: Incorrect polarity can reduce fusion and arc stability.

stem: How should power source polarity be chosen?

choices.text: Use the same polarity for all processes
Follow the WPS and consumable manufacturer requirements

rationales.CHOICE-2: Different processes and wires/rods require specific polarity for proper fusion.

stem: If unexpected porosity appears, a first troubleshooting step is to:

choices.text: Check gas flow/coverage and surface cleanliness

rationales.CHOICE-2: Verify shielding gas and cleanliness before changing parameters.

stem: Why rotate parts on a positioner/turntable when possible?

choices.text: To weld in the flat position for better quality and deposition
To remove the need for fit‑up

rationales.CHOICE-2: Flat‑position welding improves control and productivity.

stem: Before production welding on a new setup, a good approach is to:

choices.text: Run practice beads on scrap of similar material and thickness

rationales.CHOICE-2: Practice beads help dial in parameters and technique.

stem: How should preheat be verified?

choices.text: With temperature‑indicating crayons or a thermometer

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use objective temperature indicators to confirm required preheat.

stem: Excessive preheat beyond WPS requirements may:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Too much preheat can coarsen microstructure and increase distortion.

stem: What is a reliable way to verify preheat temperature?

choices.text: Using temperature‑indicating crayons or a thermometer

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use objective temperature indicators to confirm preheat.

stem: What is the purpose of a root face (land) on a groove?

choices.text: To help control root penetration and support the root
To eliminate the need for backing

rationales.CHOICE-2: A small land helps control root penetration and bead shape.

stem: Run‑on/run‑off tabs are installed to:

choices.text: Start/stop off the part and achieve full fusion at tie‑ins

rationales.CHOICE-2: Tabs allow full penetration and clean tie‑ins without damaging part edges.

stem: Shielding gas flow for GMAW/GTAW should be set to:

choices.text: The highest possible to be safe
Provide stable coverage without turbulence or aspiration
A fixed value for all nozzles

rationales.CHOICE-2: Set flow to protect the pool; too much flow causes turbulence and air entrainment.

stem: Skip or back‑step welding sequences are used mainly to:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Heat distribution reduces distortion and residual stress.

stem: What should be done between weld passes with flux‑shielded processes?

choices.text: Water‑quench slag to speed the job

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cleaning between passes prevents slag inclusions and improves fusion.

stem: Between passes with flux‑shielded processes you should:

choices.text: Leave slag; it will burn out

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cleaning prevents slag inclusions and promotes fusion.

stem: On stainless steel, use a wire brush that is:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Avoid cross‑contamination; use stainless‑only brushes on stainless.

stem: For low‑hydrogen electrodes on many applications, it is preferable to use:

choices.text: Stringer beads or limited weave per WPS

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stringers help control heat input and hydrogen cracking risk.

stem: Why remove oil, rust, paint, and mill scale before welding?

choices.text: To reduce porosity and lack of fusion

rationales.CHOICE-2: Contaminants cause gas generation and prevent fusion at the interface.

stem: How should tack welds be placed to control distortion?

choices.text: All tacks on one side of the joint
Balanced around the joint to hold alignment

rationales.CHOICE-2: Balanced, adequate tacks hold fit‑up and reduce distortion during welding.

stem: How should tack welds be prepared for incorporation into the final weld?

choices.text: Feather/clean tacks so they fuse smoothly into the weld

rationales.CHOICE-2: Feathered, clean tacks reduce lack‑of‑fusion at tie‑ins.

stem: Increasing travel speed (all else equal) generally:

choices.text: Lowers heat input and narrows the bead

rationales.CHOICE-2: Higher travel speed reduces heat input and penetration.

stem: When using powered wire brushes, wear:

choices.text: No eye protection; bristles are soft
Safety glasses and a face shield

rationales.CHOICE-2: Wire bristles can eject; use both glasses and a face shield.

stem: Convert shielding gas flow of 20 CFH to L/min (round to 0.1).

rationales.CHOICE-2: 1 CFH ≈ 0.472 L/min → 20 CFH ≈ 9.4 L/min.

stem: How many L/min is 25 CFH? (to 0.1)
For a fillet weld with an 8 mm leg, compute the effective throat (t ≈ 0.707 × leg).
An electrode diameter of 1/8" is approximately how many millimeters (to 0.01)?
A fillet leg of 5/16" equals approximately how many mm (to 0.01)?
Estimate heat input H (kJ/mm) with V=24 V, I=180 A, travel speed=300 mm/min, η=0.8. Formula: H ≈ (V·I·60·η)/(1000·speed).
If speed rises from 300 to 450 mm/min with the same V, I, η, heat input will:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Heat input is inversely proportional to speed: 300/450 ≈ 0.67 (−33%).

stem: Drawing: root gap 3.0 ± 0.5 mm. Measurement is 2.6 mm. Decision?
Required fillet leg 8 ± 1 mm. Measured 6.9 mm. Your action:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Minimum is 7 mm; 6.9 mm fails.

stem: Starting range of argon flow for GTAW with cup #8 (normal indoor conditions, no drafts):

rationales.CHOICE-2: Typical starting point for #8 is about 10–12 L/min; adjust for stickout/drafts.

stem: For a 1/4" fillet, compute the effective throat t (in mm, to 0.01). (t≈0.707×leg; 1/4"≈6.35 mm)
WPS: max interpass 150 °C. Measured 165 °C. Correct action?

choices.text: Stop, cool to within limits, and document

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stay within WPS; cool and record non‑conformance if required.

stem: GMAW on carbon steel: sudden porosity; gas type/flow correct and cylinder is new. What to check first?

rationales.CHOICE-1: Air entrainment/leaks commonly cause fresh porosity.

stem: GTAW: darkened/oxidized bead with signs of contamination. Likely cause and action?

choices.text: Contaminated tungsten/contact with pool—regrind tungsten, clean work, verify gas lens and flow

rationales.CHOICE-1: Contaminated electrodes and poor shielding drive oxidation.

stem: Vertical‑up SMAW (E7018 Ø3.2 mm). Most suitable technique:

choices.text: Short arc, stringer or limited triangle/weave; current per WPS

rationales.CHOICE-2: Shorter arcs and controlled motion suit vertical‑up with 7018.

stem: Long fillet weld on thin sheet warps the part. Best plan:

choices.text: Skip/back‑step short segments, alternate sides, use fixturing and balanced tacks

rationales.CHOICE-2: Sequence, fixturing, and symmetry control distortion.

stem: Weld a bracket to galvanized stock in the shop. Best steps:

choices.text: Weld through zinc; increase gas flow
Strip local zinc, provide extraction/PPE per hazards, then weld to WPS

rationales.CHOICE-2: Remove coating and control fumes per procedure.

stem: Stray arc strikes found outside the weld area. Correct repair:

choices.text: Grind to sound metal with smooth transitions; VT and NDE as required by plan

rationales.CHOICE-2: Remove hardened zone and document/control per route plan.

stem: Edge of the part must be clean by drawing. How to ensure full fusion at start/stop?

choices.text: Use run‑on/run‑off tabs; remove per requirement
Immediately cap with a heavy pass

rationales.CHOICE-2: Tabs permit clean tie‑ins and full penetration.

stem: Pipe‑to‑flange: access limited. What improves quality/productivity?

choices.text: Lock the positioner and weld as‑is
Rotate on a positioner to flat, secure, then weld

rationales.CHOICE-2: Flat position improves control and deposition.

stem: Butt joint 1000 mm in thin sheet. How to place tacks to minimize warping?

choices.text: Small, even tacks along the length and symmetrically; then skip sequence

rationales.CHOICE-2: Even, balanced tacks hold alignment and limit distortion.

stem: Assembly requires preheat. Edge is below minimum but center is above. What should you do?

choices.text: Achieve required temperature at the edge in the weld zone; re‑verify and document

rationales.CHOICE-2: Meet preheat at the joint edges where it matters most for HAZ.

stem: Temporary backing used; drawing requires REMOVAL. Choose the correct procedure.

choices.text: Leave it; blend the edge and paint
Remove per WPS/drawing (mechanical/gouge/cut); grind to required finish/flatness; VT and NDE if required; record in router
Remove on one side only; no router notes
Remove, then hide defects with primer without inspection

rationales.CHOICE-2: Follow the qualified procedure and document/inspect as specified.

stem: Air‑carbon gouging assigned to remove backing/lack of fusion. Best step set:

choices.text: Set current/air per WPS; PPE + extraction; control depth/geometry; then blend smooth, VT, NDE as required; record in router
Gouge extra deep 'for safety'; skip blending
Replace with grinder only, no checks

rationales.CHOICE-2: Controlled removal, finish, and inspection are required.

stem: After backing removal at the root of a groove weld—what inspection is justified?

choices.text: VT mandatory; PT/MT if required by WPS/inspection plan/code

rationales.CHOICE-2: Apply the specified NDE after material removal at critical locations.

stem: Stray arc strikes outside weld zone—correct sequence:

choices.text: Paint the arc strikes and continue
Stop; mark area; remove heat‑affected metal with light grinding to smooth transition; VT and PT/MT as required; record in router/NCR if needed; add prevention (strike pads, holder insulation check)
Cut out a large area without inspection

rationales.CHOICE-2: Proper repair + documentation and preventive actions.

stem: What documentation is expected when removing backing/repairing arc strikes?

choices.text: Record operation/inspection in the router; file NCR/repair disposition if needed; secure inspector sign‑off at hold‑points

rationales.CHOICE-2: Maintain traceability and required approvals.

stem: After an arc‑strike incident, which preventive actions make sense?

choices.text: Use strike pads/tabs, check insulation of holder/cables, conduct a short toolbox talk
Strike on machined surfaces for convenience

rationales.CHOICE-2: Engineering/behavioral controls reduce recurrence.

stem: Two steels (wt.%). Plate A: C 0.18, Mn 1.2, Cr 0.50, Mo 0.10, V 0.05, Ni 0.10, Cu 0.20. Plate B: C 0.12, Mn 1.0, Cr 0.20, Mo 0.00, V 0.02, Ni 0.10, Cu 0.10. Using IIW CE = C + Mn/6 + (Cr+Mo+V)/5 + (Ni+Cu)/15, which plate likely requires higher preheat (see WPS)?

choices.text: CE does not affect preheat choice

rationales.CHOICE-1: Calculated CE is higher for A → generally higher preheat.

stem: Exceeding interpass temperature versus WPS typically results in:

choices.text: Higher Charpy toughness (CVN) and grain refinement
Lower CVN, grain coarsening, and risk of unfavorable HAZ microstructure
Always improves properties and reduces residual stress

rationales.CHOICE-2: Interpass control influences grain size and toughness.
